Walnut kernel pellicle, a by-product of the walnut industry, is rich in polyphenols. However, research on walnut kernel pellicle polyphenols (WPP) remains limited, and the composition and bioactivity of WPP are influenced by extraction methods, gastrointestinal digestion, and colonic fermentation. Therefore, this study aimed to optimize subcritical water extraction (SWE) and NKA-9 resin purification of WPP. Next, the changes in WPP throughout simulated gastrointestinal digestion and colonic fermentation were evaluated. The results demonstrated that SWE achieved higher polyphenol yield compared to ultrasound-assisted extraction, with ellagic acid and ellagitannins as the main components. Although digestion and fermentation reduced WPP contents and antioxidant activities, they facilitated the biotransformation of ellagic acid and ellagitannins into urolithins. Meanwhile, WPP modulated the gut microbiota by promoting beneficial bacteria. Additionally, WPP enhanced beneficial microbial metabolites, including short-chain fatty acids and indole derivatives. These findings highlighted the potential of WPP as a functional ingredient for gut health. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Highlights • Subcritical water-extracted walnut pellicle polyphenols (WPP) are ellagitannins-rich. • WPP content and activity decreases to some content after gastrointestinal digestion. • WPP enhances beneficial gut microbiota while suppressing harmful bacteria. • WPP can promote short chain fatty acids levels produced by gut microbiota. • WPP can promote indole derivatives levels produced by gut microbiota. The walnut kernel pellicle powder was prepared by drying, crushing, and then sieving it through a 60-mesh screen. Subsequently, single-factor experiments and response surface methodology (RSM) were employed to determine the optimal conditions for extracting WPP from the powder using SWE. Three single factors are as follows: Temperatures (100, 110, 120, 140, 160, and 180 °C), time (5, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 min), and solid-liquid ratios (1:30, 1:40, 1:50, 1:60, 1:70, 1:80 g/mL). The three factors and levels for response surface methodology (RSM) are as follows: temperatures (100, 110, and 120 °C); time (5, 15, and 25 min); solid-liquid ratios (1:40, 1:50, and 1:60 g/mL). After extraction, the supernatant was collected by centrifugation (3000 g 2.3 Purification of WPP Macroporous resin was used to purify the crude WPP. Firstly, the optimal resin for purifying crude WPP was screened by evaluating its adsorption and desorption rates. Then, the concentration and pH of crude WPP, and the ethanol volume fraction for washing WPP, were determined using static adsorption-desorption experiments. Subsequently, dynamic adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out to derive the up-sampling flow rate and volume. Briefly, macroporous resin was packed into a φ1.6 cm × 26 cm glass column, and the crude WPP solution (2 mg/mL, pH = 2) was loaded onto the column at a flow rate of 1 mL/min, 2 mL/min, and 3 mL/min. Subsequently, WPP was eluted with 45 % ethanol at a flow rate of 2 mL/min. Effluent was collected until the polyphenol content reached the leakage point of 1/10. The collected eluate fractions were concentrated and freeze-dried to obtain purified WPP. 2.4 Identification of WPP components Ultra-performance liquid chromatography quadrupole Orbitrap tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-Q-Orbitrap-MS 2 18 m z d 2.5 Detection of polyphenol contents The total WPP content was determined using the Folin-Ciocalteu method. Lipinska et al., 2014 After colonic fermentation, most WPP components exhibited further degradation, presumably due to microbial utilization. While there were still some fractions that increased first and then decreased. The content of trigalloyl-HHDP-glucose increased from 20.54 to 50.91 μg/mL after 6 h of fermentation, and then decreased to 19.91 μg/mL after 48 h of fermentation. The content of bis-HHDP-glucose increased from 14.39 to 23.09 μg/mL at 12 h fermentation, and then decreased to 19.11 μg/mL at 48 h fermentation. Ellagic acid was increased from 0 to 24 h, while it decreased greatly at 48 h, which may be due to some ellagitannins being converted into ellagic acid at 0–24 h, while ellagic acid was metabolized into urolithins by the intestinal microbiota. Urolithins are products of ellagic acid metabolism by the gut microbiota. In support of this metabolic pathway, we detected several urolithin metabolites. Trigalloyl-HHDP-glucose and galloyl-bis-HHDP-glucose undergo initial hydrolysis, facilitated by enzymatic activity, gut microbiota, or acidic/alkaline conditions, releasing galloyl units and yielding intermediates such as galloyl-HHDP-glucose and HHDP-glucose. The HHDP is highly unstable and rapidly undergoes spontaneous lactonization to form ellagic acid. Additionally, ellagic acid derivatives, including ellagic acid hexoside and ellagic acid pentoside, can be hydrolyzed under similar conditions (acidic/alkaline environments or microbial action) to release ellagic acid along with their corresponding sugar moieties. Subsequently, ellagic acid can be further metabolized by the gut microbiota through a series of dehydroxylation and decarboxylation reactions, ultimately yielding bioactive urolithins such as Urolithin A, B, and C.
